subject: Re: Identity Crisis
msgSnippet: Glad to have you as a new member. I selected the name Read Alphabet when I started the group site as a result of what I perceived to be the dismissive
messageBody:
Glad to have you as a new member.

I selected the name "Read Alphabet" when I started the group site as a result of what I perceived to be the dismissive attitude toward QS of many of those in the Shavian group at the time. My memory is that another member of the Shavian group, who was also primarily interested in QS as I was, did not want to see a permanent split between the two groups and hoped that avoiding Read's name (Quikscript)for the revised Shavian might help avoid that consequence. I acquiesced in that at the time, although now I wish I had not. I doubt that Yahoogroups will let me rename the group now, and it has been Read's Alphabet for a long time.


Paige Gabhart


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Zyggy2" <jayson@...> wrote:
>
> Hello all, new member first post. For no readily apparent reason, I've become attached to Quikscript and have found it to be an excellent way to kill conversations at lunch with coworkers. Thus I find myself in this corner of the internet hoping to learn more.
>
> In short intervals, I've put in a few months learning. I'm still getting up to speed on my reading and putting in the heavy lifting of learning vowels, but can do many of the basics automatically. Evidently, it is an advantage having a simple midwestern accent which obviates the need for some vowels or the troublesome #20.
>
> In my searching, I have come up with some recurring themes that perhaps someone might venture to answer.
>
> Why is the Quikscript alphabet called the Read Alphabet here (including the group's name)? I cannot find any real reference to how this came about. My only guess is that someone with a cruel sense of humor wanted others to google "read alphabet"...
>
> I get that Kingsley Read created it and that someone is probably trying to honor him, but he called it Quikscript in his original manual so one would think that would be enough. Bringing up the manual reminds me that Mr. Read spelled quikscript as quickscript as well. Which leads to more confusion on what to search for. Fortunately, Wikipedia redirects people to a single page.
>
> Where did the term Second Shaw come in? Mysteriously, it is featured prominently in Wikipedia, but that is the pretty much last time you will find reference to it. I've read the history of the Shaw Alphabet, but cannot guess why there is yet another name for QS.
>
> Writing about Wikipedia reminds me, does anyone else find it puzzling that next to the detailed description about 40 letters there is a graphic (originating from Mr. Tremblay, I believe) showing 50 symbols. It takes some digging to discover that the extra symbols are ligatures and the Scottish additions to the alphabet.
>
> Thanks for any response, I'm off to read Cthulhu (pdf version).
>
> Jayson
>
